"#4678AA" : "#4477AA"}); }"}},"evals":["options.rowCallback"],"jsHooks":[]} This correlation table contains all variables corresponding to constructs in the model, albeit differently specified (see Descriptive Statistics table). Further, Knowledge is specified differently: Instead of a pseudo-continuous scale with 1 corresponding to an incorrect answer, 2 to a ‘don’t know’ and 3 to an correct answer, there are counts of how often a respondent answered correctly, incorrectly, or ‘don’t know’. There is also a Subjective Knowledge variable which is a self-assessment of the amount of a respondent’s climate crisis related knowledge. Most of the correlations mirror relationships are already expressed in the model. Additionally, there are the following correlations (\( ho > 0.3\)) which all are significant at the p < 0.001 level: Behavior is strongly correlated with Behavioral Intention, moderately correlated with Perceived Self-Efficacy, Perceived Response Efficacy and Personal Moral Norm, and weakly correlated with Perceived Susceptibility, Perceived Severity, Descriptive Norm, and Injunctive Norm. It is also weakly and negatively correlated with all dimensions of Distrusting Beliefs in Science. Behavioral Intention is strongly correlated with Perceived Self-Efficacy and Perceived Response Efficacy, moderately correlated with Perceived Susceptibility, Perceived Severity, and Personal Moral Norm, and weakly correlated with Perceived Response Costs, Descriptive Norm, Injunctive Norm, and Subjective Knowledge. It is also weakly and negatively correlated with all dimensions of Distrusting Beliefs in Science. All Response Beliefs lower-order constructs are intercorrelated, with the correlation between Perceived Self-Efficacy and Perceived Response Efficacy being strong, and those with Perceived Response Costs being weak. Perceived Self-Efficacy and Perceived Response Efficacy are (at a minimum) moderately correlated with Perceived Susceptibility, Perceived Severity, Personal Moral Norm, and Descriptive Norm. The relationship between Perceived Response Efficacy and Personal Moral Norm is strong, and Perceived Response Efficacy is weakly correlated with Subjective Knowledge. Both Perceived Self-Efficacy and Perceived Response Efficacy are weakly and negatively correlated with all Distrust Beliefs variables. Perceived Response Costs is weakly correlated with Personal Moral Norm. Perceived Susceptibility and Perceived Severity are strongly intercorrelated. Perceived Susceptibility is moderately correlated with Personal Moral Norm, and negatively and moderately correlated with the Distrusting Beliefs variables. It is weakly correlated with Injunctive Norm and Descriptive Norm. Perceived Severity on the other hand is strongly correlated with Personal Moral Norm, moderately positively correlated with Descriptive Norm, moderately negatively correlated with the Distrusting Beliefs variables, and weakly correlated with Injunctive Norm and the number of correct answers to Knowledge questions. All normative variables are moderately intercorrelated. Additionally, Personal Moral Norm is moderately and negatively correlated with the Distrusting Beliefs variables, and weakly correlated with Subjective Knowledge. Descriptive Norm is weakly and negative correlated with all Distrusting Beliefs dimensions. All Distrusting Beliefs variables are strongly intercorrelated. Subjective Knowledge is weakly positively correlated with the number of correct answers, and negatively correlated with the number of questions respondents did not know an answer to. "#FEFCFC" : null}); }"}},"evals":["options.rowCallback"],"jsHooks":[]} Next, we focus in on the correlations between all continuous variables and Behavioral Intention as well as Behavior and the different types of Behavior. Apart from the correlations already discussed, it becomes apparent that correlations differ between the different types of Behavior. COVID-19 Behavioral Intention and COVID-19 Behavior are both weakly correlated with Climate Crisis Behavioral Intention and Climate Crisis Behavior. None of the Big Five variables show a substantial (\( ho > 0.3\)) significant correlation with any type of Behavior or Behavioral Intention, nor do Internal or External Control Conviction Further, there are no perceptible correlations for age, the household size, or the number of children living in the household. Kruskal-Wallis test and Wilcoxon signed-rank test for categorical variables As the data for Behavior is non-parametric, we use the Kruskal Wallis test, the Pairwise Wilcoxon Rank Sum test and the Wilcoxon-Mann-Whitney test to detect group differences. The weighst for Distrusting Beliefs Integrity and Injunctive Norm are not significant, but the loadings are sufficiently large. All other weights are significant and relevant. The mode B higher-order constructs can be retained as hypothesized. Results summary To improve internal consistency reliability of Personal Norm, CCPN2 should be deleted. Other than that, the mode A measurement model can be retained as-is. Because there are incorrigible problems with convergent validity for the Response Belief lower-order constructs and Behavioral Intention, four distinct behavior-specific models should be estimated next. The other mode B higher-order constructs can be retained as-is.

Evaluation of the mode A measurement model Convergent validity Ideally, outer loadings (l) should be \(\geq\) 0.70. Loadings below 0.40 are unacceptable. AVE should be > 0.50. Internal consistency reliability Both Cronbach’s a and composite reliability rc should be \(\geq\) 0.60 and \(\leq\) 0.90. The upper threshold of acceptability is 0.95. Discriminant validity Discriminant validity is evaluated using the heterotrait-monotrait ratio (HTMT). With that, there are no issues with collinearity. The weight for Perceived Response Costs is non-significant, and the loading is not sufficiently large. Therefore, it should be removed. All other weights are significant and relevant. Results of the mode B higher-order constructs evaluation Perceived Response Costs has to be removed, otherwise the mode B higher-order constructs can be retained as-is. Results summary Perceived Response Costs has to be removed as a lower-order construct.

Evaluation of the mode A measurement model Convergent validity Ideally, outer loadings (l) should be \(\geq\) 0.70. Loadings below 0.40 are unacceptable. AVE should be > 0.50. Internal consistency reliability Both Cronbach’s a and composite reliability rc should be \(\geq\) 0.60 and \(\leq\) 0.90. The upper threshold of acceptability is 0.95. Discriminant validity Discriminant validity is evaluated using the heterotrait-monotrait ratio (HTMT). "#ff9999" : "#00"}); }"}},"evals":["options.columnDefs.0.render","options.rowCallback"],"jsHooks":[]} The effect sizes of Threat Beliefs, Personal Moral Norm, and Subjective Norm on Behavioral Intention, as well as the effect size of Knowledge on Response Beliefs, are below 0.2. The effect of Knowledge on Threat Beliefs is small. The effect of Distrusting Beliefs on Response Beliefs is medium. And the effects of Response Beliefs and Behavioral Intention and of Distrusting Beliefs on Threat Beliefs are large. Out-of-sample predictive performance Out-of-sample predictive performance has to be evaluated using a simplified model without HOCs as an approximation as seminr as of now does not support plspredict for HOC. If the root mean square error (RMSE) or the mean absolute deviation (MAD) of the naive LM model is below the ones for the PLS model, this indicates a lack of predictive performance. However, a lack of predictive performance does not imply a lack of explanatory power. {"x":{"filter":"none","caption":"Out-of-sample predictive performance","data":[["PLS RMSE","LM RMSE","RMSE Difference","PLS MAD","LM MAD","MAD Difference"],[1.32718908667389,1.09269799109751,-0.234491095576375,1.05041789469521,0.843805892973722,-0.206612001721487],[1.2129877150924,0.995788652735898,-0.217199062356503,0.953395312612557,0.772501364306592,-0.180893948305964],[1.11817678940061,1.06764957635826,-0.0505272130423531,0.864620328194841,0.832182500178696,-0.0324378280161448],[1.22686041890983,1.14455921206821,-0.082301206841616,0.946940732968737,0.868635295216056,-0.0783054377526815],[1.12869649658389,1.07617993605893,-0.0525165605249649,0.87407487064321,0.838127074222178,-0.0359477964210317],[0.985014532558466,0.886090744306633,-0.0989237882518326,0.749055423625094,0.658733627386467,-0.0903217962386262],[0.868154238554605,0.774058039720199,-0.0940961988344061,0.686214940551457,0.584040630452103,-0.102174310099354],[1.24502372038054,1.11806555918543,-0.126958161195107,0.951163822075275,0.867528017492394,-0.083635804582881],[1.08186354620332,1.09880691719089,0.0169433709875666,0.842645499407022,0.847001035357322,0.00435553595029936]],"container":"

Evaluation of the mode B measurement model There are no simple mode B constructs to evaluate. Evaluation of the mode B higher-order constructs Convergent validity Convergent validity cannot be evaluated. Collinearity The variance inflation factor (VIF) should be < 5, ideally \(\leq\) 3. Significance and relevance Indicator weights should be significant (t \(\geq\) 1.65, bootstrapping CI does not include 0). Otherwise, the loading l should be \(\geq\) 0.50. Any positive indicator weight implies relevance. {"x":{"filter":"top","filterHTML":"
","caption":"Results of the mode B higher-order construct evaluation","data":[["Response Beliefs","Response Beliefs","Distrusting Beliefs","Distrusting Beliefs","Distrusting Beliefs"],["Perceived Self-Efficacy","Perceived Response Efficacy","Benevolence","Competence","Integrity"],[1.74967561798873,1.74967561798873,3.11642548312659,4.79486838077139,4.80304349755742],[0.436983597286796,0.657817739617333,0.299027571282517,0.364597463260259,0.398935124398525],[0.438110966542311,0.655406274587021,0.293691945868223,0.356468703258025,0.401135644170295],[6.97765033905139,11.0538874518278,1.74027955350524,1.5627875003771,1.7445163207376],[false,false,true,true,true],[0.867573165732372,0.943855295678034,0.908104410050485,0.951732866469745,0.956176409762095]],"container":"

'' : value <= 3 ? "#00" : value <= 5 ? "#ffe5e5" : "#ff9999"}); var value=data[5]; $(this.api().cell(row, 5).node()).css({'background-color':isNaN(parseFloat(value)) ? '' : value <= 1.649 ? "#ffe5e5" : "#00"}); var value=data[7]; $(this.api().cell(row, 7).node()).css({'background-color':isNaN(parseFloat(value)) ? '' : value <= 0.499 ? "#ff9999" : "#00"}); var value=data[6]; $(this.api().cell(row, 6).node()).css({'background-color':value == 1 ? "#ffe5e5" : value == 0 ? "#00" : null}); }"}},"evals":["options.columnDefs.0.render","options.columnDefs.1.render","options.columnDefs.2.render","options.columnDefs.3.render","options.columnDefs.4.render","options.rowCallback"],"jsHooks":[]} The VIFs for the Distrusting Beliefs are above 3, but still below 5. With that, there are no issues with collinearity. All other weights are significant and relevant. Results of the mode B higher-order constructs evaluation All mode B higher-order constructs can be retained as-is. Results summary All measurement model parts meet quality criteria. Therefore, structural model evaluation can commence.

The other VIF values are below 3. In-sample predictive power In-sample predictive power is assessed using variance explained R². R² \(\geq\) 0.75 indicates substantial in-sample predictive power, R² \(\geq\) 0.5 moderate and R² \(\geq\) 0.25 weak in-sample predictive power. R² \(\leq\) 0.10 indicates a lack of model predictiveness. {"x":{"filter":"top","filterHTML":"

R² for Behavioral Intention is above 0.25, indicating weak in-sample predictive power at a minimum. Effect size Effect size f2² measures the impact of a predictor construct on an endogenous construct. f² \(\geq\) 0.35 indicates a large effect, f² \(\geq\) 0.15 a medium and f² \(\geq\) 0.02 a small effect. {"x":{"filter":"top","filterHTML":"
","caption":"Effect sizes","data":[["Distrusting Beliefs","Knowledge","Response Beliefs"],["Response Beliefs","Response Beliefs","Behavioral Intention"],[0.205976960420503,0.016612777086309,0.757196348226553]],"container":"

The effect of Distrusting Beliefs on Response Beliefs is medium. And the effect of Response Beliefs on Behavioral Intention is large. Out-of-sample predictive performance Out-of-sample predictive performance has to be evaluated using a simplified model without HOCs as an approximation as seminr as of now does not support plspredict for HOC. If the root mean square error (RMSE) or the mean absolute deviation (MAD) of the naive LM model is below the ones for the PLS model, this indicates a lack of predictive performance. However, a lack of predictive performance does not imply a lack of explanatory power. {"x":{"filter":"none","caption":"Out-of-sample predictive performance","data":[["PLS RMSE","LM RMSE","RMSE Difference","PLS MAD","LM MAD","MAD Difference"],[1.33702189755303,1.08426372902525,-0.25275816852778,1.05705031126068,0.836763749288331,-0.220286561972345],[1.22554732409116,1.01438925140052,-0.211158072690637,0.957687807495625,0.780275657133612,-0.177412150362013],[1.07484016931381,1.07931169745598,0.00447152814216634,0.835422365627408,0.8429133688236,0.00749100319619278]],"container":"

All others are below the critical thresholds. Results of the evaluation of the mode A measurement model The mode A measurement model meets all quality criteria and can be retained as-is. Evaluation of the mode B measurement model There are no simple mode B constructs to evaluate. Evaluation of the mode B higher-order constructs Convergent validity Convergent validity cannot be evaluated. Collinearity The variance inflation factor (VIF) should be < 5, ideally \(\leq\) 3. Significance and relevance Indicator weights should be significant (t \(\geq\) 1.65, bootstrapping CI does not include 0). Otherwise, the loading l should be \(\geq\) 0.50. Any positive indicator weight implies relevance. {"x":{"filter":"top","filterHTML":"

'' : value <= 3 ? "#00" : value <= 5 ? "#ffe5e5" : "#ff9999"}); var value=data[5]; $(this.api().cell(row, 5).node()).css({'background-color':isNaN(parseFloat(value)) ? '' : value <= 1.649 ? "#ffe5e5" : "#00"}); var value=data[7]; $(this.api().cell(row, 7).node()).css({'background-color':isNaN(parseFloat(value)) ? '' : value <= 0.499 ? "#ff9999" : "#00"}); var value=data[6]; $(this.api().cell(row, 6).node()).css({'background-color':value == 1 ? "#ffe5e5" : value == 0 ? "#00" : null}); }"}},"evals":["options.columnDefs.0.render","options.columnDefs.1.render","options.columnDefs.2.render","options.columnDefs.3.render","options.columnDefs.4.render","options.rowCallback"],"jsHooks":[]} The VIFs for the Distrusting Beliefs are above 3, but still below 5. With that, there are no issues with collinearity. All other weights are significant and relevant. Results of the mode B higher-order constructs evaluation All mode B higher-order constructs can be retained as-is. Results summary All measurement model parts meet quality criteria. Therefore, structural model evaluation can commence.

articles.contents:

VIF should be < 5, ideally \(\leq\) 3. {"x":{"filter":"top","filterHTML":"
","caption":"Results of the structural collinearity assessment","data":[["Distrusting Beliefs","Response Beliefs"],["Response Beliefs","Behavioral Intention"],[null,null]],"container":"
Exogenous Construct Endogenous Construct VIF

'' : value <= 3 ? "#00" : value <= 5 ? "#ffe5e5" : "#ff9999"}); }"}},"evals":["options.columnDefs.0.render","options.rowCallback"],"jsHooks":[]} There are no VIF values available - likely because there is only one exogenous construct for each endogenous construct. In-sample predictive power In-sample predictive power is assessed using variance explained R². R² \(\geq\) 0.75 indicates substantial in-sample predictive power, R² \(\geq\) 0.5 moderate and R² \(\geq\) 0.25 weak in-sample predictive power. R² \(\leq\) 0.10 indicates a lack of model predictiveness. {"x":{"filter":"top","filterHTML":"
","caption":"In-sample predictive power","data":[["Response Beliefs","Behavioral Intention"],[0.180404280014839,0.431174451022434],[0.178489336743845,0.429845419365945]],"container":"
Construct R² R²adj
","options":{"pageLength":2,"columnDefs":[{"targets":1,"render":"function(data, type, row, meta) { return type !== 'display' ? data : DTWidget.formatRound(data, 3, 3, ",", "."); }"},{"targets":2,"render":"function(data, type, row, meta) { return type !== 'display' ? data : DTWidget.formatRound(data, 3, 3, ",", "."); }"},{"className":"dt-right","targets":[1,2]}],"order":[],"autoWidth":false,"orderClasses":false,"orderCellsTop":true,"lengthMenu":[2,10,25,50,100],"rowCallback":"function(row, data, displayNum, displayIndex, dataIndex) { var value=data[1]; $(this.api().cell(row, 1).node()).css({'background-color':isNaN(parseFloat(value)) ? '' : value <= 0.1 ? "#ff9999" : value <= 0.249 ? "#ffe5e5" : value <= 0.9 ? "#00" : "#ff9999"}); }"}},"evals":["options.columnDefs.0.render","options.columnDefs.1.render","options.rowCallback"],"jsHooks":[]} R² is below 0.25 for Response Beliefs, but not below 0.1. R² for Behavioral Intention is above 0.25, indicating weak in-sample predictive power at a minimum. Effect size Effect size f2² measures the impact of a predictor construct on an endogenous construct. f² \(\geq\) 0.35 indicates a large effect, f² \(\geq\) 0.15 a medium and f² \(\geq\) 0.02 a small effect. {"x":{"filter":"top","filterHTML":"
","caption":"Effect sizes","data":[["Distrusting Beliefs","Response Beliefs"],["Response Beliefs","Behavioral Intention"],[0.220113740977204,0.758008236088284]],"container":"
Exogenous Construct Endogenous Construct f²
","options":{"columnDefs":[{"targets":2,"render":"function(data, type, row, meta) { return type !== 'display' ? data : DTWidget.formatRound(data, 3, 3, ",", "."); }"},{"className":"dt-right","targets":2}],"order":[],"autoWidth":false,"orderClasses":false,"orderCellsTop":true,"rowCallback":"function(row, data, displayNum, displayIndex, dataIndex) { var value=data[2]; $(this.api().cell(row, 2).node()).css({'background-color':isNaN(parseFloat(value)) ? '' : value <= 0.019 ? "#ff9999" : "#00"}); }"}},"evals":["options.columnDefs.0.render","options.rowCallback"],"jsHooks":[]} The effect of Distrusting Beliefs on Response Beliefs is medium. And the effect of Response Beliefs on Behavioral Intention is large. Out-of-sample predictive performance Out-of-sample predictive performance has to be evaluated using a simplified model without HOCs as an approximation as seminr as of now does not support plspredict for HOC. If the root mean square error (RMSE) or the mean absolute deviation (MAD) of the naive LM model is below the ones for the PLS model, this indicates a lack of predictive performance. However, a lack of predictive performance does not imply a lack of explanatory power. {"x":{"filter":"none","caption":"Out-of-sample predictive performance","data":[["PLS RMSE","LM RMSE","RMSE Difference","PLS MAD","LM MAD","MAD Difference"],[1.33769831103248,1.07647983030827,-0.261218480724201,1.05611412579825,0.834389770081275,-0.221724355716971],[1.22998878327936,1.01954307788971,-0.210445705389649,0.953920181535857,0.784240639739024,-0.169679541796833],[1.07594566507229,1.0837712364252,0.00782557135290607,0.834045845997684,0.840778805771595,0.00673295977391131]],"container":"

Loadings below 0.40 are unacceptable. AVE should be > 0.50. Internal consistency reliability Both Cronbach’s a and composite reliability rc should be \(\geq\) 0.60 and \(\leq\) 0.90. The upper threshold of acceptability is 0.95. Discriminant validity Discriminant validity is evaluated using the heterotrait-monotrait ratio (HTMT). '' : value <= 3 ? "#00" : value <= 5 ? "#ffe5e5" : "#ff9999"}); var value=data[5]; $(this.api().cell(row, 5).node()).css({'background-color':isNaN(parseFloat(value)) ? '' : value <= 1.649 ? "#ffe5e5" : "#00"}); var value=data[7]; $(this.api().cell(row, 7).node()).css({'background-color':isNaN(parseFloat(value)) ? '' : value <= 0.499 ? "#ff9999" : "#00"}); var value=data[6]; $(this.api().cell(row, 6).node()).css({'background-color':value == 1 ? "#ffe5e5" : value == 0 ? "#00" : null}); }"}},"evals":["options.columnDefs.0.render","options.columnDefs.1.render","options.columnDefs.2.render","options.columnDefs.3.render","options.columnDefs.4.render","options.rowCallback"],"jsHooks":[]} The VIFs for the Distrusting Beliefs are above 3, but still below 5. With that, there are no issues with collinearity. The weight for Perceived Response Costs is non-significant on the basis of the bootstrap confidence interval, and the loading is not sufficiently large. Therefore, the construct should be removed. The weight for Distrusting Beliefs Integrity is als non-significant, but with a sufficiently large loading, the construct can be retained. For Injunctive Norm, the weight is negative, not relevant, and the loading is bordering the 0.5 threshold. Therefore, it should also be removed as a lower-order construct. All other weights are significant and relevant. Results of the mode B higher-order constructs evaluation Perceived Response Costs and Injunctive Norm have to be removed, otherwise the mode B higher-order constructs can be retained as-is. Results summary Perceived Response Costs and Injunvtive Norm have to be removed as a lower-order constructs.

Evaluation of the mode B measurement model There are no regular mode B constructs left to evaluate. Evaluation of the mode B higher-order constructs Convergent validity Convergent validity cannot be evaluated. Collinearity The variance inflation factor (VIF) should be < 5, ideally \(\leq\) 3. Significance and relevance Indicator weights should be significant (t \(\geq\) 1.65, bootstrapping CI does not include 0). Otherwise, the loading l should be \(\geq\) 0.50. Any positive indicator weight implies relevance. {"x":{"filter":"top","filterHTML":"

All other weights are significant and relevant. Results of the mode B higher-order constructs evaluation All mode B higher-order constructs can be retained as-is. Results summary The measurement model can be retained as is. Structural model evaluation can commence.

"#ffe5e5" : "#ff9999"}); }"}},"evals":["options.columnDefs.0.render","options.rowCallback"],"jsHooks":[]} There is no VIF information for the path from Distrusting Beliefs to Response Beliefs as Distrusting Beliefs is the only predictor. Other than that, all VIF values are below 1.4. In-sample predictive power In-sample predictive power is assessed using variance explained R². R² \(\geq\) 0.75 indicates substantial in-sample predictive power, R² \(\geq\) 0.5 moderate and R² \(\geq\) 0.25 weak in-sample predictive power. R² \(\leq\) 0.10 indicates a lack of model predictiveness. {"x":{"filter":"top","filterHTML":"
","caption":"In-sample predictive power","data":[["Response Beliefs","Behavioral Intention"],[0.162586417922347,0.288705187970036],[0.160629844132446,0.285373596344603]],"container":"
Construct R² R²adj
","options":{"pageLength":2,"columnDefs":[{"targets":1,"render":"function(data, type, row, meta) { return type !== 'display' ? data : DTWidget.formatRound(data, 3, 3, ",", "."); }"},{"targets":2,"render":"function(data, type, row, meta) { return type !== 'display' ? data : DTWidget.formatRound(data, 3, 3, ",", "."); }"},{"className":"dt-right","targets":[1,2]}],"order":[],"autoWidth":false,"orderClasses":false,"orderCellsTop":true,"lengthMenu":[2,10,25,50,100],"rowCallback":"function(row, data, displayNum, displayIndex, dataIndex) { var value=data[1]; $(this.api().cell(row, 1).node()).css({'background-color':isNaN(parseFloat(value)) ? "#00" : "#ff9999"}); }"}},"evals":["options.columnDefs.0.render","options.columnDefs.1.render","options.rowCallback"],"jsHooks":[]} R² is below 0.25 for Response Beliefs, but not below 0.1. The R² value for Behavioral Intention is above 0.25, indicating weak in-sample predictive power. Effect size Effect size f2² measures the impact of a predictor construct on an endogenous construct. f² \(\geq\) 0.35 indicates a large effect, f² \(\geq\) 0.15 a medium and f² \(\geq\) 0.02 a small effect. {"x":{"filter":"top","filterHTML":"
","caption":"Effect sizes","data":[["Distrusting Beliefs","Response Beliefs","Personal Moral Norm"],["Response Beliefs","Behavioral Intention","Behavioral Intention"],[0.194153070122131,0.117350463854379,0.0734103726857306]],"container":"
Exogenous Construct Endogenous Construct f²
","options":{"columnDefs":[{"targets":2,"render":"function(data, type, row, meta) { return type !== 'display' ? data : DTWidget.formatRound(data, 3, 3, ",", "."); }"},{"className":"dt-right","targets":2}],"order":[],"autoWidth":false,"orderClasses":false,"orderCellsTop":true,"rowCallback":"function(row, data, displayNum, displayIndex, dataIndex) { var value=data[2]; $(this.api().cell(row, 2).node()).css({'background-color':isNaN(parseFloat(value)) ? '' : value <= 0.019 ? "#ff9999" : "#00"}); }"}},"evals":["options.columnDefs.0.render","options.rowCallback"],"jsHooks":[]} All effect sizes are above 0.02. Out-of-sample predictive performance Out-of-sample predictive performance has to be evaluated using a simplified model without HOCs as an approximation as seminr as of now does not support plspredict for HOC. If the root mean square error (RMSE) or the mean absolute deviation (MAD) of the naive LM model is below the ones for the PLS model, this indicates a lack of predictive performance. However, a lack of predictive performance does not imply a lack of explanatory power. {"x":{"filter":"none","caption":"Out-of-sample predictive performance","data":[["PLS RMSE","LM RMSE","RMSE Difference","PLS MAD","LM MAD","MAD Difference"],[1.18645906800739,1.14221505769803,-0.0442440103093649,0.900906676887563,0.873503464506345,-0.0274032123812183],[1.09005254612871,0.990323304384543,-0.0997292417441645,0.831635138090765,0.768281404739931,-0.0633537333508346],[1.30074560443211,1.33448424740328,0.033738642971163,1.03126514719369,1.05822128234408,0.0269561351503844]],"container":"

For Injunctive Norm, the weight is negative, not relevant, but the loading is sufficiently large. All other weights are significant and relevant. Results of the mode B higher-order constructs evaluation All mode B constructs can be retained as is. Results summary The measurement model can be retained as-is. Structural model evaluation can commence.

articles.title: Climate Crisis Iteration 2-c-1 (Driving) Nonlinearity Evaluation
articles.contents:
Contents
Test for possible nonlinearity
Test alternate models with quadratic effectsEffect of Distrusting Beliefs on Response Belief

Summary

Test for possible nonlinearity
First, we test for nonlinearity by applying Ramsey’s RESET test for functional form to each partial linear model of the SEM. As quadratic effects of higher-order constructs cannot (yet) be estimated using PLS-SEM, we also apply the test to the corresponding partial linear models of the proxy SEM without higher order constructs. If the test statistic is significant, the respective partial regression might be nonlinear.


{"x":{"filter":"none","caption":"<caption>Results of Ramsey's RESET test for nonlinearity<\/caption>","data":[["Distrusting Beliefs","Distrusting Beliefs proxy","Knowledge","Knowledge proxy","Distrusting Beliefs","Distrusting Beliefs proxy","Knowledge","Knowledge proxy","Response Beliefs","Response Beliefs proxy","Threat Beliefs","Threat Beliefs proxy","Personal Moral Norm","Personal Moral Norm proxy","Subjective Norm","Subjective Norm proxy"],["Response Beliefs","Response Beliefs proxy","Response Beliefs","Response Beliefs proxy","Threat Beliefs","Threat Beliefs proxy","Threat Beliefs","Threat Beliefs proxy","Behavioral Intention","Behavioral Intention proxy","Behavioral Intention","Behavioral Intention proxy","Behavioral Intention","Behavioral Intention proxy","Behavioral Intention","Behavioral Intention proxy"],[3.48607897290662,2.6773790111,0.637374023011189,0.556215130371141,7.5476175548146,8.11936127146797,4.30330211161635,4.63348517770753,2.28734165146912,2.24262581806683,0.0927069597069509,0.0665691226988808,0.120403849445401,0.120403849445401,1.17406305654192,2.16310532583513],[0.0314971285968691,0.0698998642090373,0.529182300599335,0.573790943368475,0.000600966924576862,0.000346220890988687,0.0141165355511164,0.0102159282434147,0.102781763014029,0.107431482837593,0.911478939466702,0.935607973092426,0.886592486209683,0.886592486209683,0.310106602774544,0.116228697301619],[2,2,2,2,2,2,2,2,2,2,2,2,2,2,2,2],[426,426,426,426,426,426,426,426,426,426,426,426,426,426,426,426]],"container":"<table class=\"display\">\n  <thead>\n    <tr>\n      <th>Independent variable<\/th>\n      <th>Response variable<\/th>\n      <th>Test statistic<\/th>\n      <th>p<\/th>\n      <th>DF 1<\/th>\n      <th>DF 2<\/th>\n    <\/tr>\n  <\/thead>\n<\/table>","options":{"columnDefs":[{"targets":2,"render":"function(data, type, row, meta) {\n    return type !== 'display' ? data : DTWidget.formatRound(data, 3, 3, \",\", \".\");\n  }"},{"targets":3,"render":"function(data, type, row, meta) {\n    return type !== 'display' ? data : DTWidget.formatRound(data, 3, 3, \",\", \".\");\n  }"},{"className":"dt-right","targets":[2,3,4,5]}],"order":[],"autoWidth":false,"orderClasses":false}},"evals":["options.columnDefs.0.render","options.columnDefs.1.render"],"jsHooks":[]}
Using p = 0.05 as a threshold, there are potential nonlinear effects in the partial regression equation for the influence of Distrusting Beliefs on Response Beliefs. The same is potentially true for the effects of Distrusting Beliefs and Knowledge on Threat Beliefs, but as Threat Beliefs will be removed from the model because of a lack of effect, these potential effects will not be examined further.
Test alternate models with quadratic effects
To test for nonlinearity, one can model an interaction term of the exogenous construct with itself.
Effect of Distrusting Beliefs on Response Belief











































































Unfortunately, the alternate model cannot be estimated.
Summary
Using the available tests, we did not find evidence for a quadratic influence of any of the exogenous variables.

The upper threshold of acceptability is 0.95. Discriminant validity Discriminant validity is evaluated using the heterotrait-monotrait ratio (HTMT). The HTMT bootstrap confidence interval should not contain 1. {"x":{"filter":"top","filterHTML":"

All others are below the critical thresholds. Results of the evaluation of the mode A measurement model The mode A measurement model meets all quality criteria and can be retained as-is. Evaluation of the mode B measurement model There are no simple mode B constructs to evaluate. Evaluation of the mode B higher-order constructs Convergent validity Convergent validity cannot be evaluated. Collinearity The variance inflation factor (VIF) should be < 5, ideally \(\leq\) 3. Significance and relevance Indicator weights should be significant (t \(\geq\) 1.65, bootstrapping CI does not include 0). Otherwise, the loading l should be \(\geq\) 0.50. Any positive indicator weight implies relevance. {"x":{"filter":"top","filterHTML":"

'' : value <= 3 ? "#00" : value <= 5 ? "#ffe5e5" : "#ff9999"}); var value=data[5]; $(this.api().cell(row, 5).node()).css({'background-color':isNaN(parseFloat(value)) ? '' : value <= 1.649 ? "#ffe5e5" : "#00"}); var value=data[7]; $(this.api().cell(row, 7).node()).css({'background-color':isNaN(parseFloat(value)) ? '' : value <= 0.499 ? "#ff9999" : "#00"}); var value=data[6]; $(this.api().cell(row, 6).node()).css({'background-color':value == 1 ? "#ffe5e5" : value == 0 ? "#00" : null}); }"}},"evals":["options.columnDefs.0.render","options.columnDefs.1.render","options.columnDefs.2.render","options.columnDefs.3.render","options.columnDefs.4.render","options.rowCallback"],"jsHooks":[]} The VIFs for the Distrusting Beliefs are above 3, but still below 5. With that, there are no issues with collinearity. The weight for Distrusting Beliefs Integrity is non-significant, but with a sufficiently large loading, the construct can be retained. All other weights are significant and relevant. Results of the mode B higher-order constructs evaluation All mode B constructs can be retained as is. Results summary The measurement model can be retained as-is. Structural model evaluation can commence.

'' : value <= 3 ? "#00" : value <= 5 ? "#ffe5e5" : "#ff9999"}); }"}},"evals":["options.columnDefs.0.render","options.rowCallback"],"jsHooks":[]} As every endogenous construct has only one predictor, there is no VIF information available. In-sample predictive power In-sample predictive power is assessed using variance explained R². R² \(\geq\) 0.75 indicates substantial in-sample predictive power, R² \(\geq\) 0.5 moderate and R² \(\geq\) 0.25 weak in-sample predictive power. R² \(\leq\) 0.10 indicates a lack of model predictiveness. {"x":{"filter":"top","filterHTML":"
","caption":"In-sample predictive power","data":[["Response Beliefs","Behavioral Intention"],[0.190309531531477,0.530623072755859],[0.188417731371504,0.529526397692204]],"container":"

"#00" : "#ff9999"}); }"}},"evals":["options.columnDefs.0.render","options.columnDefs.1.render","options.rowCallback"],"jsHooks":[]} R² is below 0.25 for Response Beliefs, but not below 0.1. The R² value for Behavioral Intention is above 0.5, indicating moderate in-sample predictive power. Effect size Effect size f2² measures the impact of a predictor construct on an endogenous construct. f² \(\geq\) 0.35 indicates a large effect, f² \(\geq\) 0.15 a medium and f² \(\geq\) 0.02 a small effect. {"x":{"filter":"top","filterHTML":"
","caption":"Effect sizes","data":[["Distrusting Beliefs","Response Beliefs"],["Response Beliefs","Behavioral Intention"],[0.235039856516325,1.13048392870803]],"container":"
Exogenous Construct Endogenous Construct f²
","options":{"columnDefs":[{"targets":2,"render":"function(data, type, row, meta) { return type !== 'display' ? data : DTWidget.formatRound(data, 3, 3, ",", "."); }"},{"className":"dt-right","targets":2}],"order":[],"autoWidth":false,"orderClasses":false,"orderCellsTop":true,"rowCallback":"function(row, data, displayNum, displayIndex, dataIndex) { var value=data[2]; $(this.api().cell(row, 2).node()).css({'background-color':isNaN(parseFloat(value)) ? '' : value <= 0.019 ? "#ff9999" : "#00"}); }"}},"evals":["options.columnDefs.0.render","options.rowCallback"],"jsHooks":[]} All other effect sizes are substantial. Out-of-sample predictive performance Out-of-sample predictive performance has to be evaluated using a simplified model without HOCs as an approximation as seminr as of now does not support plspredict for HOC. If the root mean square error (RMSE) or the mean absolute deviation (MAD) of the naive LM model is below the ones for the PLS model, this indicates a lack of predictive performance. However, a lack of predictive performance does not imply a lack of explanatory power. {"x":{"filter":"none","caption":"Out-of-sample predictive performance","data":[["PLS RMSE","LM RMSE","RMSE Difference","PLS MAD","LM MAD","MAD Difference"],[1.54190827625268,1.18619019002426,-0.355718086228414,1.2569036417651,0.926413603847437,-0.330490037917667],[1.18585253814785,0.993207700796548,-0.192644837351305,0.904876021138678,0.767760422888956,-0.137115598249722],[1.58458138559461,1.41109089307218,-0.173490492522431,1.29900141894365,1.13195762274037,-0.167043796203278],[1.07938640418029,1.08547943428966,0.00609303010937112,0.829705373805509,0.825901475464216,-0.0038038983412928]],"container":"

Evaluation of the mode A measurement model Convergent validity Ideally, outer loadings (l) should be \(\geq\) 0.70. Loadings below 0.40 are unacceptable. AVE should be > 0.50. Internal consistency reliability Both Cronbach’s a and composite reliability rc should be \(\geq\) 0.60 and \(\leq\) 0.90. The upper threshold of acceptability is 0.95. Discriminant validity Discriminant validity is evaluated using the heterotrait-monotrait ratio (HTMT). The weights for Distrusting Beliefs Integrity and Injunctive Norm are non-significant, but the loadings are sufficiently large. Therefore they can be retained. All other weights are significant and relevant. Results of the mode B higher-order constructs evaluation All mode B higher-order constructs meet expectations and can be retained. Results summary The measurement model can be retained as is. Structural model evaluation can commence.

All other effect sizes are small at a minimum. Out-of-sample predictive performance Out-of-sample predictive performance has to be evaluated using a simplified model without HOCs as an approximation as seminr as of now does not support plspredict for HOC. If the root mean square error (RMSE) or the mean absolute deviation (MAD) of the naive LM model is below the ones for the PLS model, this indicates a lack of predictive performance. However, a lack of predictive performance does not imply a lack of explanatory power. {"x":{"filter":"none","caption":"Out-of-sample predictive performance","data":[["PLS RMSE","LM RMSE","RMSE Difference","PLS MAD","LM MAD","MAD Difference"],[0.92002175958802,0.774581762785081,-0.14543999680294,0.709619139622026,0.618390376715024,-0.0912287629070019],[1.17131654215556,1.01865429756436,-0.152662244591203,0.899788420975725,0.771557616309471,-0.128230804666254],[1.22455166248044,1.21501010740934,-0.00954155507109711,0.986121647721858,0.974571708723886,-0.0115499389979719],[1.11554586307955,1.07140322769027,-0.0441426353892822,0.869432191270423,0.832165395456892,-0.0372667958135312],[1.23614956398203,1.14132638825705,-0.0948231757249793,0.958496712106188,0.865863035526736,-0.0926336765794517],[1.1355280763576,1.07334594590968,-0.0621821304479244,0.883602715697764,0.833922721649798,-0.0496799940479657],[0.988230664534261,0.892146318290104,-0.0960843462441564,0.751348747996367,0.665866178827488,-0.0854825691688792],[0.873251189176053,0.769983985877365,-0.103267203298687,0.692906150287385,0.580946053651191,-0.111960096636194],[1.24398024503567,1.11365275683542,-0.130327488200249,0.957386873786937,0.852564787947001,-0.104822085839936],[0.855461277352752,0.878717741198926,0.0232564638461737,0.668456626083756,0.692435170933192,0.0239785448494357]],"container":"

"#00" : null}); }"}},"evals":["options.columnDefs.0.render","options.columnDefs.1.render","options.columnDefs.2.render","options.columnDefs.3.render","options.columnDefs.4.render","options.rowCallback"],"jsHooks":[]} The VIFs for the Distrusting Beliefs are above 3, but still below 5. The weights for Distrusting Beliefs Integrity and Injunctive Norm are non-significant, but the loadings are sufficiently large. Therefore they can be retained. All other weights are significant and relevant. Results of the mode B higher-order constructs evaluation All mode B higher-order constructs meet expectations and can be retained. Results summary The measurement model can be retained as is. Structural model evaluation can commence.

articles.title: Climate Crisis Iteration 2-d-2 (General) Structural Model Evaluation
articles.contents:

95% CI [0.14, 0.348] >, penwidth = 1.69, style = solid, color = black] } }","config":{"engine":"dot","options":null}},"evals":[],"jsHooks":[]} Collinearity Collinearity is assessed using the variance inflation factor (VIF). VIF should be < 5, ideally \(\leq\) 3. {"x":{"filter":"top","filterHTML":"
","caption":"Results of the structural collinearity assessment","data":[["Distrusting Beliefs","Response Beliefs","Personal Moral Norm","Subjective Norm"],["Response Beliefs","Behavioral Intention","Behavioral Intention","Behavioral Intention"],[null,2.50912090707572,2.57151571837277,1.75938667818028]],"container":"

'' : value <= 3 ? "#00" : value <= 5 ? "#ffe5e5" : "#ff9999"}); }"}},"evals":["options.columnDefs.0.render","options.rowCallback"],"jsHooks":[]} There is no VIF information for the path from Distrusting Beliefs to Response Beliefs, as Distrusting Beliefs is the only predictor. Other than that, all VIF values are below 3. In-sample predictive power In-sample predictive power is assessed using variance explained R². R² \(\geq\) 0.75 indicates substantial in-sample predictive power, R² \(\geq\) 0.5 moderate and R² \(\geq\) 0.25 weak in-sample predictive power. R² \(\leq\) 0.10 indicates a lack of model predictiveness. {"x":{"filter":"top","filterHTML":"
","caption":"In-sample predictive power","data":[["Response Beliefs","Behavioral Intention"],[0.274901639847125,0.532785362352123],[0.273207484800039,0.529495118425026]],"container":"
Construct R² R²adj
","options":{"pageLength":2,"columnDefs":[{"targets":1,"render":"function(data, type, row, meta) { return type !== 'display' ? data : DTWidget.formatRound(data, 3, 3, ",", "."); }"},{"targets":2,"render":"function(data, type, row, meta) { return type !== 'display' ? data : DTWidget.formatRound(data, 3, 3, ",", "."); }"},{"className":"dt-right","targets":[1,2]}],"order":[],"autoWidth":false,"orderClasses":false,"orderCellsTop":true,"lengthMenu":[2,10,25,50,100],"rowCallback":"function(row, data, displayNum, displayIndex, dataIndex) { var value=data[1]; $(this.api().cell(row, 1).node()).css({'background-color':isNaN(parseFloat(value)) ? '' : value <= 0.1 ? "#ff9999" : value <= 0.249 ? "#ffe5e5" : value <= 0.9 ? "#00" : "#ff9999"}); }"}},"evals":["options.columnDefs.0.render","options.columnDefs.1.render","options.rowCallback"],"jsHooks":[]} All R² values are above 0.25, indicating weak in-sample predictive power at a minimum. Effect size Effect size f2² measures the impact of a predictor construct on an endogenous construct. f² \(\geq\) 0.35 indicates a large effect, f² \(\geq\) 0.15 a medium and f² \(\geq\) 0.02 a small effect. {"x":{"filter":"top","filterHTML":"
","caption":"Effect sizes","data":[["Distrusting Beliefs","Response Beliefs","Personal Moral Norm","Subjective Norm"],["Response Beliefs","Behavioral Intention","Behavioral Intention","Behavioral Intention"],[0.379123240313448,0.0559461720190306,0.0917307487463863,0.0687201802216508]],"container":"
Exogenous.Construct Endogenous.Construct f²
","options":{"columnDefs":[{"targets":2,"render":"function(data, type, row, meta) { return type !== 'display' ? data : DTWidget.formatRound(data, 3, 3, ",", "."); }"},{"className":"dt-right","targets":2}],"order":[],"autoWidth":false,"orderClasses":false,"orderCellsTop":true,"rowCallback":"function(row, data, displayNum, displayIndex, dataIndex) { var value=data[2]; $(this.api().cell(row, 2).node()).css({'background-color':isNaN(parseFloat(value)) ? '' : value <= 0.019 ? "#ff9999" : "#00"}); }"}},"evals":["options.columnDefs.0.render","options.rowCallback"],"jsHooks":[]} All effects are small at a minimum. Out-of-sample predictive performance Out-of-sample predictive performance has to be evaluated using a simplified model without HOCs as an approximation as seminr as of now does not support plspredict for HOC. If the root mean square error (RMSE) or the mean absolute deviation (MAD) of the naive LM model is below the ones for the PLS model, this indicates a lack of predictive performance. However, a lack of predictive performance does not imply a lack of explanatory power. {"x":{"filter":"none","caption":"Out-of-sample predictive performance","data":[["PLS RMSE","LM RMSE","RMSE Difference","PLS MAD","LM MAD","MAD Difference"],[0.923925065263141,0.757095508725378,-0.166829556537763,0.705424182811476,0.59806072245299,-0.107363460358487],[1.16933294114048,0.995062453526053,-0.174270487614429,0.897242041011377,0.758714555895128,-0.138527485116249],[1.22563999377708,1.19639233742538,-0.0292476563517077,0.990637031915561,0.960646594729118,-0.0299904371864435],[0.851861654756549,0.864029203542738,0.0121675487861885,0.664175574068028,0.681177687616887,0.0170021135488587]],"container":"

articles.title: Predictors for climate protective behavior - accompanying website
articles.description: This website contains supplementary material for our paper on predictors for climate protective behavior in Germany. Specifically, we detail the process of model evaluation and provide the full results of the additional exploratory data analysis.
